history.content: Preferably you want to take 61b soon, so the concepts are still fresh and you won't have to do much work. This summer and fall are ideal. Though summer might still have gitlet as a project. I'm not sure what Hug's projects will be like for fall, but it might be to your advantage to take the summer version if it turns out that their projects overlaps more with this semester's.

children.subject:
"Pre-reqs for this class will be enforced during week 1 of the class."

What are the prereqs? I can't find the catalog. For 61C, it's clearly 61B.
Darn. I guess I’ll just take 61B and 70 this fall. How are exams for 70 because it’s online?

<md>They’ve been very reasonable about the exams. The format reflects the in-person course as well as they possibly could. With that being said, it is generally considered to be the most conceptually difficult out of all the lower div classes, though the curve is generous.</md>

I also would not recommend taking 61B along with 170 if you are not sure about your content in 61B..because 170 builds on the concepts in 61b. I know people who have done that...but I dont know how it works and 170 in Fall will be enforcing prereqs

Thanks for the exhaustive response. Very detailed. Wow! 

I’m a bit worried about taking 61BL in the summer since it has harsh grade bins: 300 points with 20 maximum one can lose for an A. I’m leaning toward taking 61B and 70 next fall, using this summer to prep, and just graduating in spring 2022.

What are your opinions on that? And why 162? I’m trying to fit UD classes that’ll make me the most employable upon graduation. I know 170 is one.

Of course, it's always a better idea to take you time (so 70 + 61B in the fall is a better option if you are willing to graduate Sp2022). However, since you'll need to make up for your 61A grade, I'd suggest you do only do those two classes, and maybe a really light breadth with them (take minimal units). Once you declare, you can go nuts on the classes, but just make sure you maximize your ability to declare.

You can read past posts for why 162 in terms of employability. Of all of the UD CS courses 170 and 162 are probably the most core courses to take, and 162 material will pop up in interviews and/or on the job for most people. 170 is just generally a good class to take since it dips into many areas of CS, is relevant for interviews (not so much for the actual job), and builds on your ability to solve problems. After these, in terms of "employability" which I take to mean standard SWE or developer job, I'd suggest 161, 186, 168 (I would suggest 160 for front-end dev jobs, but nobody gets to take it without priority enrollment).

However, if you graduate from Berkeley CS you are by default "employable," it's not super important that you take a certain set of classes. Just make sure you have some variety of classes in which you have had extensive programming assignments (i.e. if you want to be maximally employable don't just take all theory courses). Any of the 16X and most of the 18X courses will help you get some kind of SWE job so just take what interests you.
Uh 162 since you are more likely to deal with systems than come up with fancy algorithms irl (if you are thinking about industry, SWE).
I personally think 162 should be required like most of other CS departments, but again Berkeley has really liberal requirements (and doesn’t help much if you wanna do pure theory research).

The second schedule you proposed has some problems with prerequisites. I would suggest:

spring 2020: EECS 16B

summer 2020: cs 61B

fall 2020: cs 61c, cs 70

spring 2021: cs 188, cs 161 cs 170

fall 2021: cs 189,169

This way you meet prerequisites for classes  (61B+ 70 before 170, 61C before 161). Keep in mind you still have to take two upper div. technical electives if you haven't already (I would probably add one to Fa2020 and Fa2021 if I were you). Keep in mind that while you can technically take 189 with this schedule, its not a good idea without a bit more linear algebra/probability/optimization background you get from other classes (see the many Piazza posts on this). Since it seems like you want to get your degree asap, I would maybe recommend a different class than 189 since it seems like most of your other UD classes are slightly more SWE-slated/programming heavy. If your plan is to do SWE I'd recommend swapping 189 or another one of your UDs with 162.

history.content:
I might have to cut my losses for 61B. Deadline tomorrow. Gitlet not working. I was originally planning on doing the following.

spring 2020: cs 61b (may drop), EECS 16B (passed 🎉)

summer 2020: cs 70

fall 2020: cs 61c, cs 170

spring 2021: cs 188, cs 161

fall 2021: cs 188, 169

Let's say I drop 61B and take the following schedule (I wanna be out of here by fall 2021). Would you say this is a sound choice? I was consdering 61BL this summer, but it looks pretty rough considering the grade bins (not sure if it's optimal to take 61B this summer or 70), and I wanna try Hug's iteration of the class out for a different experience.  

spring 2020: EECS 16B (passed 🎉)

summer 2020: cs 70

fall 2020: cs 61b, cs 170

spring 2021: cs 188, cs 161 cs 61c

fall 2021: cs 189,169
